comments:
Download an evaluation copy of WFTPD server from http://www.wftpd.com/
Start wftpd.exe
In wftpd, choose Security > Users / Rights
Press "New User"; Username=d, Password=d, Homedirectory=I:\

Connect RSE to "FTP Only" on localhost.
Expand the My Home folder, enter user+pass=d.
RSE shows "Expand failed. File system input or output error".

The Error log shows the following exception:
org.apache.commons.net.ftp.parser.ParserInitializationException: Unknown parser type: WIN32 A N (WFTPD by Texas Imperial Software)
	at org.apache.commons.net.ftp.parser.DefaultFTPFileEntryParserFactory.createFileEntryParser(DefaultFTPFileEntryParserFactory.java:118)
	at org.apache.commons.net.ftp.FTPClient.initiateListParsing(FTPClient.java:2358)
	at org.apache.commons.net.ftp.FTPClient.listFiles(FTPClient.java:2141)
	at org.apache.commons.net.ftp.FTPClient.listFiles(FTPClient.java:2188)
	at org.eclipse.rse.services.files.ftp.FTPService$1.run(FTPService.java:754)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)


The FTP Console shows the following:

-----------Enter bugs above this line-----------
RSE 1.0 Release Test
installation : eclipse-SDK-3.2.1
RSE install  : update-site RSE 1.0 complete
java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03
os.name:     : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 1
------------------------------------------------
systemtype   : FTP Only
targetos     : WFTPD 3.23
------------------------------------------------

WIN32 is not automatically recongnised by the file listing parser.
After investigating the listing returned by wftpd, it looks similar (if not exact) to the UNIX listing. Something similar happends with VMS server.
Using the UNIX parser could be a solution.

Looking at DefaultFTPFileEntryParserFactory I see that the system string WINDOWS is recognized while WIN32 is not. 

Perhaps what we'd want is derive from the DefaultFTPFileEntryParserFactory (e.g. RSEFTPFileEntryParserFactory) and add our own matching algorithm for returning a Windows parser in case the system string is WIN32 or MSDOS.

wftpd reports to be a WIN32 system, but uses unix-style listing format.

The FTP RFC gives complete freedom to the implementation of the file listing:
"Since the information on a file may vary widely from system to system, this information may be hard to use automatically in a program, but may be quite useful to a human user."

So, what RSE could do is try to match the remote system (reported through the SYST command) with the ones supported by the Jakarta FTP parser: 

FTPClientConfig.SYST_NT = "WINDOWS"	
FTPClientConfig.SYST_MVS = "MVS"	
FTPClientConfig.SYST_OS2 = "OS/2"	
FTPClientConfig.SYST_OS400 = "OS/400"	
FTPClientConfig.SYST_UNIX = "UNIX"	
FTPClientConfig.SYST_VMS = "VMS"	

and leave UNIX-style parsing as the default in case the server doesn't match, since it's the most widely used.
I'm fine with everything that works ok. UNIX style fallback instead of just throwing a "cannot parse" exception is perhaps a good idea anyways.
wftpd is now parsed using the default UNIX style

traces.message: Unknown parser type: WIN32 A N (WFTPD by Texas Imperial Software)
